etymology.description: 當(當) (dāng, "to be; to work as") + 然(然) (rán, "like this; correct") = it is correct to be like this -> of course; certainly
etymology.interpretation: The word is a combination of 當(當) (dāng, "to be; to work as") suggesting a state of being, and 然(然) (rán, "like this; correct"), indicating something correct or true. Together, they form the expression for something that is naturally or evidently so, akin to the phrase 'of course' in English.

examples.chinese: 你当然知道这件事(你當然知道這件事)。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ dāngrán zhīdào zhè jiàn shì.
examples.english: You certainly know about this matter.

examples.chinese: 他努力学习(他努力學習)，当然会取得好成绩(當然會取得好成績)。
examples.pinyin: Tā nǔlì xuéxí, dāngrán huì qǔdé hǎo chéngjì.
examples.english: He studies hard, so of course he will achieve good results.

examples.chinese: 天气变冷了(天氣變冷了)，当然你应该添件衣服(當然你應該添件衣服)。
examples.pinyin: Tiānqì biàn lěng le, dāngrán nǐ yīnggāi tiān jiàn yīfu.
examples.english: The weather has turned cold, so of course you should put on another piece of clothing.
